facts: Built by the Dutch in 1765 in Matara under Governor Lubbert Jan van Eck
Unique six-pointed star shape designed for defensive artillery coverage
Only star-shaped fort in Sri Lanka; built after 1762 Matara rebellion to prevent surprise attacks
Constructed with coral stone and lime mortar; features bastions named after Dutch officials
Restored by Sri Lankan Department of Archaeology in 2000s; now houses a small museum
Star Fort.significance: Rare example of 18th-century European military architecture in South Asia; symbol of Dutch colonial engineering adapted to local threats

facts: Built by King Kashyapa I (477-495 CE) as a palace-fortress atop 200m granite rock
Features ancient frescoes of 'Sigiriya Maidens' (21 surviving figures) painted 5th century CE
Includes sophisticated water gardens with symmetrical pools, fountains, and moats
Mirror Wall: polished plaster surface with 6th-10th century graffiti poems in ancient Sinhala
Lion's Paw entrance: massive brick paws flanking staircase (original lion head destroyed)
Abandoned after Kashyapa's death; later used as Buddhist monastery until 14th century
UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1982
Sigiriya.significance: Masterpiece of ancient urban planning; considered one of world's oldest landscaped gardens and most dramatic archaeological sites

facts: Sri Lanka's largest national park (1,317 sq km) in North Western Province
Name means 'Land of Lakes' â€“ contains over 60 natural sand-rimmed water basins (villus)
Established as wildlife sanctuary in 1905; declared national park in 1938
Key species: Sri Lankan leopard, sloth bear, elephant, mugger crocodile, 200+ bird species
Ancient archaeological sites within park: Kudumbigala monastery complex, Veheragala ruins
Wilpattu National Park.significance: Critical biodiversity hotspot and watershed area; represents Sri Lanka's dry zone ecosystem with unique villu hydrology

facts: Established in 1975 by Sri Lankan Department of Wildlife Conservation near Kegalle
World's largest elephant orphanage caring for 90+ orphaned/injured elephants
Daily river bathing ritual at Ma Oya River (10am & 2pm) attracts tourists
Successful captive breeding program: first birth in 1984; over 70 calves born on-site
Controversy: modern conservationists advocate for wild rehabilitation over captivity
Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage.significance: Pioneering wildlife rescue initiative; raises awareness about elephant conservation while facing evolving ethical debates in animal welfare

facts: 2,243m mountain in central Sri Lanka with sacred footprint summit shrine
Buddhists: footprint of Buddha (Sri Pada); Hindus: Shiva's footprint; Muslims/Christians: Adam's footprint
Pilgrimage season: December to May (dry season); 5,500+ steps to summit
Bell tradition: pilgrims ring bells at each of 4 rest stops during ascent
Sunrise spectacle: 'triangle shadow' phenomenon where mountain casts perfect triangular shadow at dawn
Adam's Peak.significance: Unique multi-faith pilgrimage site symbolizing Sri Lanka's religious harmony; spiritually significant across Buddhism, Hinduism, Islam and Christianity

facts: Highland plateau at 2,100-2,300m elevation in Central Highlands
Formed by ancient glacial activity; part of UNESCO World Heritage Site 'Central Highlands of Sri Lanka' (2010)
World's End: dramatic 870m sheer cliff with panoramic views (best at 6:30am before clouds form)
Mini World's End: smaller 300m cliff nearby
Home to endemic species: sambar deer, purple-faced langur, Sri Lankan whistling thrush
Critical watershed: source of Mahaweli, Kelani and Walawe rivers
Horton Plains.significance: Vital cloud forest ecosystem protecting Sri Lanka's water sources; showcases unique montane grassland-shola forest mosaic

facts: Located near Bandarawela in Uva Province; carved into granite rock face
Features 2,000-year-old unfinished Buddha image (15m tall) carved directly into rock
Local legend: carving abandoned when British colonial authorities halted work in 19th century
Temple complex includes meditation caves used by Buddhist monks for centuries
Lesser-known site offering authentic cultural experience away from tourist crowds
Dowa Rock Temple.significance: Rare example of rock-carved Buddhist art in Sri Lanka's hill country; represents continuity of monastic traditions in remote areas

facts: Last viable primary tropical rainforest in Sri Lanka (11,187 hectares)
UNESCO World Heritage Site (1988) and UNESCO Man and Biosphere Reserve (1978)
Biodiversity hotspot: 60%+ endemic tree species; 95% endemic birds; 50%+ endemic mammals
Key species: Sri Lankan leopard, purple-faced langur, red-faced malkoha, Sri Lankan junglefowl
Name means 'Lion Kingdom' in Sinhala; designated protected area in 1978
Sinharaja Forest Reserve.significance: Critical genetic reservoir for Sri Lanka's biodiversity; protects watershed for major rivers including Gin and Kalu

facts: Multiple hatcheries along west/south coasts (Kosgoda, Rekawa, Bentota most prominent)
Conservation mission: protect eggs from predators/harvesting; release hatchlings to sea
Five native species: Green, Loggerhead, Hawksbill, Olive Ridley, Leatherback turtles
Threats addressed: coastal development, plastic pollution, fishing nets, illegal egg collection
Best viewing: hatchling releases at dusk (seasonal: Nov-Apr for most species)
Turtle Hatchery.significance: Community-based conservation model balancing tourism revenue with marine protection; critical for endangered sea turtle populations

facts: Built 1273-1284 CE by King Buvanekabahu I as capital after Polonnaruwa abandonment
Dramatic 90m rock citadel with unique ornamental staircase carved from single granite block
Staircase features carved elephants, dwarfs, and moonstone with concentric bands
Buddhist temple at summit with relic chamber; influenced by South Indian Pallava architecture
Capital abandoned after 1284 Pandyan invasion; later became monastic site
Yapahuwa Rock Fortress.significance: Architectural bridge between Polonnaruwa and Kandy periods; showcases fusion of Sinhalese and South Indian artistic traditions

facts: Second ancient capital of Sri Lanka (11th-13th centuries CE) after Anuradhapura
UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1982
Key structures: Gal Vihara (4 monumental Buddha statues carved from single granite rock), Vatadage (circular relic house), Rankoth Vehera stupa (12th century)
Parakrama Samudra: 2,500-hectare reservoir built by King Parakramabahu I with inscription 'Not even a drop of water... shall be wasted'
Council Chamber: exquisitely carved stone seat with elephant friezes
Ancient City of Polonnaruwa.significance: Peak of medieval Sinhalese urban planning and hydraulic engineering; represents golden age of Sri Lankan civilization under Chola liberation

facts: Northernmost island of Sri Lanka in Palk Strait; accessible by boat from Jaffna
Colonial name: Neduntheevu; renamed by Portuguese after Dutch captured it in 1619
Unique features: wild ponies (descendants of Portuguese/Dutch imports), baobab trees, coral stone ruins
Historical sites: Dutch fort ruins, ancient Hindu temples, Portuguese well
Sparse population; traditional livelihoods: fishing, palmyrah cultivation
Delft Island.significance: Living museum of colonial encounters; represents cultural fusion of Tamil, Portuguese, Dutch and British influences in Sri Lanka's north

facts: Refers to sacred Buddha statues within Sri Dalada Maligawa (Temple of the Tooth) complex in Kandy
Most revered: statue in inner chamber near Tooth Relic casket; not publicly displayed
Daily rituals: three 'Thevava' ceremonies (5:30am, 9:30am, 6:30pm) with drumming, chanting, offerings
Annual Esala Perahera: 10-night festival (July/August) featuring statue processions on decorated elephants
Statues crafted in traditional Kandyan style with symbolic mudras (hand gestures)
Maligawa Buddha Statue.significance: Spiritual focal point of Sri Lankan Buddhism; statues serve as visual anchors for devotion to the sacred Tooth Relic

facts: Established 1998 by Department of Archaeology in Northern Province
Houses artifacts from ancient settlements in Vavuniya district dating to Anuradhapura period (377 BCE-1017 CE)
Key exhibits: pottery, coins, inscriptions, tools from early agricultural communities
Documents cultural continuity in Sri Lanka's dry zone despite civil conflict disruptions
Small but significant collection showing pre-colonial life in northern Sri Lanka
Vavuniya Archaeological Museum.significance: Preserves archaeological heritage of Sri Lanka's north; counters narrative that region lacks ancient history; supports post-war cultural reconciliation

facts: Colonial-era railway bridge in Demodara, Ella (Uva Province)
Built 1914-1921 during British Ceylon; designed by Harold Cuthbert Marwood
Engineering marvel: 30m high, 100m long; constructed entirely of brick, stone and cement (no steel)
Built to navigate mountainous terrain where railway loops back on itself ('Demodara Loop')
Still operational: carries daily passenger trains through lush tea country
Nine Arches Bridge.significance: Icon of British colonial engineering adapted to Sri Lankan landscape; symbol of plantation economy's infrastructure legacy

facts: Located in Kandy; maintained by Commonwealth War Graves Commission
Contains 194 graves from World War II (1939-1945)
Mostly Commonwealth servicemen who died in Ceylon-based hospitals
Also includes graves of Dutch and German nationals who died in internment camps
Serene garden setting with uniform white headstones and memorial wall
Annual Remembrance Day service (November) attended by diplomatic corps
British War Cemetery.significance: Quiet testament to Sri Lanka's role in global conflicts; represents Commonwealth's shared history and sacrifice beyond battlefield sites

facts: Coastal wetland park in Southern Province; Ramsar Wetland Site since 1990
Critical habitat for 197 bird species including 58 migratory species from Central Asia
Famous for greater flamingo populations (Oct-Mar); also spot crocodiles, elephants, turtles
Landscape: lagoons, marshes, mudflats, palmyrah forests along Indian Ocean coast
Established 1969; expanded 1993 to protect migratory waterfowl routes
Bundala National Park.significance: Vital stopover on Central Asian Flyway; protects coastal ecosystems threatened by climate change and development

facts: 350m tall telecommunications tower in Colombo; tallest structure in South Asia (completed 2019)
Design inspired by lotus flower (Sri Lankan national symbol) and Buddhist stupa architecture
Functions: TV/radio broadcasting, observation deck, revolving restaurant, conference facilities
Controversy: cost overruns (USD $104M) and construction delays during Mahinda Rajapaksa administration
Symbol of modern Sri Lanka's aspirations despite economic challenges
Lotus Tower.significance: Contemporary architectural landmark blending traditional symbolism with modern engineering; represents post-war development ambitions

facts: Officially 'Independence Memorial Hall'; built 1948 to commemorate Sri Lankan independence from Britain (Feb 4, 1948)
Architect: Edwin Heyn; design inspired by Kandyan-era audience halls (Magul Maduwa)
Features: 12 pillars representing ancient Sinhalese kingdoms; lion statues symbolizing sovereignty
Location: Cinnamon Gardens, Colombo; surrounded by Independence Square park
Annual independence day celebrations held here with military parade and cultural performances
Independence Square.significance: National symbol of sovereignty; architectural fusion of traditional Kandyan forms with modern civic space

facts: Established 1876 in Gampaha by British colonial government
World's first rubber plantation: 1,919 seedlings from Amazon (1876) started Sri Lanka's rubber industry
Current collection: 4,000+ plant species including giant bamboo, cannonball tree, spice gardens
Historic structures: colonial-era curator's bungalow, ornamental ponds, avenue of royal palms
Lesser-known than Peradeniya but significant for agricultural history
Henarathgoda Botanical Garden.significance: Birthplace of Sri Lanka's rubber industry that transformed 20th-century economy; living museum of colonial botanical exchange

facts: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic in Kandy; houses Buddha's left canine tooth since 4th century CE
Current structure built 1687-1707 by King Vimaladharmasuriya II; expanded by subsequent Kandyan kings
Relic chamber (Handun Kunama): innermost sanctum where casket is kept; not visible to public
Daily rituals: three 'Thevava' ceremonies with offerings of food, flowers, lighting of lamps
Annual Esala Perahera: 10-night festival (July/August) with 5,000+ participants, 100+ elephants carrying relic casket replica
UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1988
Sri Dalada Maligawa.significance: Most sacred Buddhist site in Sri Lanka; historically symbol of Sinhalese kingship (ruler possessed relic); living center of Buddhist devotion

facts: Founded 1885 in Colombo by Don Bastian de Silva; modernized by late Chief Incumbent Kiribathgoda Gnanananda Thera
Architectural fusion: Sri Lankan, Thai, Indian, Chinese and Western elements
Seema Malaka meditation hall: designed by Geoffrey Bawa (1976) floating on Beira Lake
Museum houses 5,000+ artifacts: Buddha statues, ivory carvings, colonial-era religious objects
Social services: orphanage, old age home, vocational training center
Vesak celebrations: elaborate lantern displays and free food distribution (dansal)
Gangaramaya Temple.significance: Model of modern Buddhist engagement with urban society; bridges traditional practice with contemporary social welfare

facts: Built 1876 by British colonial authorities in Beruwala (Kalutara District)
34m tall cylindrical tower painted white with red band; active aid to navigation
Strategic location: marks entrance to Beruwala harbor on southwest coast
Beruwala significance: first Muslim settlement in Sri Lanka (8th century Arab traders)
Operational: automated since 1980s; maintained by Sri Lanka Ports Authority
Surrounded by fishing village with traditional stilt houses (walauwas)
Beruwala Lighthouse.significance: Maritime heritage landmark; symbolizes Beruwala's dual identity as ancient Muslim trading port and colonial-era navigation point
